title: UK banks review Fifa allegations
desc: UK banks Barclays and Standard Chartered have begun internal reviews into whether they were used for corrupt payments by Fifa officials the BBC understands.

title: Nepal schools re-open after quake
desc: Thousands of schools - damaged during April's earthquake that killed more than 8000 people in Nepal - are beginning to re-open.

title: Joe Biden's son dies of cancer at 46
desc: Beau Biden the son of US Vice-President Joe Biden dies of brain cancer at the age of 46.

title: European anger at Russian blacklist
desc: The EU responds angrily to Russia's entry ban against 89 European politicians and top officials calling the blacklist arbitrary and unjustified.

title: US police 'kill two people a day'
desc: The number of people shot dead by US police is twice as high as official figures show suggests data gathered by The Washington Post newspaper.

title: Senate in urgent surveillance debate
desc: The US Senate is to hold an urgent session to consider extending the controversial Patriot Act on domestic surveillance which is set to expire at midnight.

title: Solar plane begins Pacific crossing
desc: Swiss pilot Andre Borschberg begins his bid to cross the Pacific from China to Hawaii in the zero-fuel Solar Impulse aeroplane.

title: Kerry breaks leg in bicycle accident
desc: US Secretary of State John Kerry is taken to hospital in Switzerland after breaking his leg in a bicycle crash in the French Alps.

title: Man shot dead near Singapore summit
desc: Singapore police shoot dead one man close to the Shangri-La hotel as an Asian security conference ends with China-US jostling over disputed islands.

title: Concern over Thai murder trial
desc: Lawyers for the men charged with the murder of two British tourists in Thailand say they are concerned key evidence will not be re-examined before trial.

title: Spinal cord injury cancer drug hope
desc: A group of drugs being trialled for cancer could also be used to make nerves regrow and treat spinal cord injuries a study in mice suggests.

title: Hawaii man killed by swordfish
desc: A 47-year-old Hawaii man dies after being impaled by a swordfish he apparently tried to catch after spotting it swimming in the harbour.

title: VIDEO: Migrant crisis: Can Kos cope alone?
desc: Authorities in Greece are struggling to deal with a rapidly growing number of migrants arriving on the island of Kos.

title: VIDEO: BB King's final Mississippi farewell
desc: The funeral of blues legend BB King has taken place in his home state of Indianola Mississippi.

title: VIDEO: Arrests at Moscow gay pride rally
desc: Russian police detain several gay rights activists for attempting to stage an unauthorised gay pride rally in central Moscow as well as detaining several anti-gay Orthodox religious counter-demonstrators.

title: VIDEO: Take-off for Solar Impulse 2
desc: Solar Impulse a plane powered entirely by the sun takes off on the most difficult leg of its mission to fly a solar plane around the world from China to Hawaii.

title: VIDEO: Dog vaccination to prevent child rabies
desc: A mass dog vaccination project in a city in Malawi is aiming to eradicate the deadly disease as Lizzie Crouch reports.

title: VIDEO: Martin O'Malley: Democratic contender?
desc: Martin O'Malley the former Governor of Maryland and Mayor of Baltimore has declared his intention to run in the Democratic presidential primaries

title: VIDEO: Splashdown for tightrope competitor
desc: Tightrope walkers compete in China but not all competitors making the crossing smoothly.

title: VIDEO: Blatter asked if Fifa is 'rotten'
desc: Fifa president Sepp Blatter has responded to questions about the arrests of Fifa officials under an American anti-corruption warrant.

title: The ethical minefield of body fat
desc: We should accept and respect people of all shapes and sizes but are we also normalising obesity asks Rob Broomby.

title: Cameron's EU tour: Mission accomplished?
desc: The BBC's Katya Adler looks whether British PM David Cameron's whistle-stop tour of the EU to push for changes in the 28-member bloc was a success.

title: Business interests propel change in China's global role
desc: The rising number of Chinese nationals working abroad is causing Beijing to adapt its foreign policy in order to protect them says Jonathan Marcus.

title: Q&A: World Heritage In Danger List
desc: What is Unesco's World Heritage In Danger List and why should we care about it?

title: How do US black students do at school?
desc: Are black children reaching their full potential at US schools - and if not why not?

title: Why the Americans took on Fifa
desc: America doesn't even like football they say so why does it want to clean it up for the world?

title: 'Meteorite thieves' held by police
desc: Police in Argentina arrest four men who appear to have been trying to steal more than a tonne of meteorites in the northern province of Chaco.

title: Berlusconi backs wrong candidate
desc: Former Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi accidentally lends his support to one of his opponents after turning up at the wrong rally.

title: Economic growth 'up several gears'
desc: The speed at which the British economy is growing is increasing the Confederation of British Industry says.

title: Prince William issues appeal to Fifa
desc: The Duke of Cambridge has urged world football body Fifa to show that it can represent the interests of fair play and put the sport first.

title: Silk Road drug site founder jailed
desc: Ross Ulbricht the founder of online illegal drug marketplace the Silk Road is sentenced to life in prison.

title: Porn adware found on FBI web domain
desc: Porn and adwarehave briefly taken over several web domains formerly owned by the FBI and used them to direct people to adware and malware sites.

title: Costume designer Julie Harris dies
desc: Oscar and Bafta-winning costume designer Julie Harris who designed clothes for the Beatles and Sir Roger Moore's James Bond dies in London aged 94.

title: Neverland ranch goes up for sale
desc: Michael Jackson's Neverland ranch has gone up for sale for $100m according to reports.

title: Strong earthquake strikes off Japan
desc: A powerful undersea earthquake south of Japan shakes buildings in the capital Tokyo and is felt across the country.

title: Drones take whale survey to the sky
desc: Scientists are using drones to monitor gray whales of the coast of California.

title: Lung cancer therapy is 'milestone'
desc: A lung cancer therapy can more than double life expectancy in some patients a major trial shows.

title: Germany 'hits global birth rate low'
desc: A study says Germany's birth rate has slumped to the lowest in the world prompting fears labour market shortages will damage the economy.

title: Platini must unite Europe - Dyke
desc: Uefa president Michel Platini must show strong leadership to unite Europe behind a boycott of the 2018 World Cup says Greg Dyke.

title: Ennis-Hill falls to fourth in Gotzis
desc: Olympic champion Jessica Ennis-Hill lies in fourth place ahead of the final two events of her first heptathlon since London 2012.

title: Pilgrimage to the mountains
desc: Photographer Timothy Allen climbs high into the Peruvian Andes for Qoyllur Rit'i - the Snow Star Festival.

title: A symbol of holding out
desc: A shabby old shop that became an architectural landmark has evaded the bulldozer.

title: Musical glass skywalk opens in China
desc: Visitors can play 70 musical notes on cliff-side path.

title: Slovak radios face native music quota
desc: Government wants radio stations to play more Slovak songs.

title: Nigeria militant attacks kill 29
desc: Militants launch deadly raids in the Nigerian city of Maiduguri including a suicide attack on a mosque after the inauguration of the new president.

title: Pakistan hosts match despite attack
desc: Pakistan will host a third and final one-day cricket international against Zimbabwe despite a deadly bomb attack near the venue of Friday's game officials say.

title: Ex-Georgia leader gets Ukraine job
desc: Former Georgian President Mikheil Saakashvili - who is wanted in his country - is appointed governor of Ukraine's southern Odessa region.

title: Thousands attend Venezuela march
desc: Thousands of Venezuelans have marched through the streets of Caracas to call for the release of opposition leaders and for the date for elections to be set.

title: Syria 'barrel bomb strikes kill 72'
desc: At least 72 people have been killed in Syria's northern Aleppo province by barrel bombs dropped from government helicopters activists say.

title: O'Malley enters US presidential race
desc: Martin O'Malley former governor of Maryland and mayor of Baltimore says he is seeking the Democratic nomination for presidential elections in 2016.

title: NHS to target 'rip-off' temp agencies
desc: The health service plans to clamp down on some of the staffing agencies ripping off the NHS the chief executive of NHS England says.

title: Russia ban 'shows sanctions working'
desc: Former Foreign Secretary Sir Malcolm Rifkind says Russia's ban on some leading Europeans shows sanctions against the country are working.

title: Cooper in 'Tory manifesto' warning
desc: Labour leadership contender Yvette Cooper makes a veiled attack on her rivals as Andy Burnham warns the party faces irrelevance.

title: Rail strike talks enter third day
desc: Talks aimed at averting a national strike by Network Rail workers in a dispute over pay enter a third day.

desc: Who won? The official poster for the 2015 festival

desc: Party time at the 60th song contest in Vienna

desc: Rare access - an Indian high court at work

desc: Ben Weller has been taking pictures of South Korea's markets

desc: Are some monks encouraging violence and hostility?

desc: Austrian plans for new smoking ban cause stir
